etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in The Epinal Glossary. Cognate with or formed similarly to Old High German bīwurz plant attractive to bees, especially white dead-nettle, water mint (Middle High German bīwurz) from the Germanic base of bee + the Germanic base of wort; compare also Old Saxon biniwurt, Old High German biniwurz, both in the sense ‘thyme, common balm’

definitions: Originally: any of several plants attractive to bees, specifically balm, Melissa officinalis (now historical). In later use: the plant sweet flag, Acorus calamus.
